abstract.p: Rita C Tobin letter on June 28 article backs Columbia University's plan for private school for children of faculty members and neighborhood children

block.p: As a Columbia University alumna whose child attended a selective public school in the Columbia area, I support the university's plan to create a private school for the children of faculty members and neighborhood children (front page, June 28).

As a Columbia University alumna whose child attended a selective public school in the Columbia area, I support the university's plan to create a private school for the children of faculty members and neighborhood children (front page, June 28).

The schools serving children in the Columbia area are plagued by all of the disabilities of the city's school system, including overcrowding, a constantly changing curriculum, high teacher turnover and the self-defeating racial politics that led District 3 to contend that a building in Central Harlem, separated from the Columbia area by Morningside Park, was an appropriate site for a school serving the Columbia community.

The proposed school will provide much-needed facilities for Columbia personnel who would otherwise be eminently justified in accepting jobs elsewhere, while enabling at least some of the many low-income children in the neighborhood to obtain the education that every child deserves.
RITA C. TOBIN New York, June 28, 2000
